report_title: Design, Editing & Rendering Software Publishing in the US
executive_summary: The Design, Editing and Rendering Software Publishing sector is undergoing a strategic transformation anchored by innovative technological advancements and progressive market dynamics. This pivot has been characterized by an unmistakable surge in demand magnified by the transition to virtual environments in numerous professions and a general increase in digital content consumption. To illustrate, the industry has seen a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 2.7% from 2019 to 2024, reaching a market size of $21.8 billion. Recent cycles have witnessed the proliferation of cutting-edge tools driven by artificial intelligence (AI), reshaping the creative landscape and optimizing workflows, albeit with emergent ethical considerations of intellectual property and the displacement of conventional artistry.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Screen Time Lifts All Boats
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As global screen time increases, demand for visually compelling content escalates, driving growth in the Design, Editing and Rendering Software industry.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Subscriptions Are The Default Method of Design Software Payment
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Design, editing and rendering software developers have progressively moved towards subscription-based service models, securing a continuous revenue stream over one-time license sales.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Many paid software providers earn huge profit on technical support and integration
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: However, the move to subscriptions has angered many smaller users, for whom a one-time license purchase for a few core features was an acceptable trade-off for lower overall costs.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Commercial building design remains slow after COVID
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The decline in demand for new commercial buildings post-COVID has caused a downturn in the use of advanced building design software, traditionally a stronghold within the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: AI Revolution in Creative Spaces: Opportunities and Ethical Quandaries
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The Design, Editing and Rendering software industry is entering an era where artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning algorithms are enhancing creative tools and raising contentious issues of copyright and the blurred lines between creatorship and AI co-creation.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: VR Developers May Leverage Specialty Features and Displays if Headset Adoption Expands
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite significant advancements in virtual (VR) and augmented reality (AR), their widespread adoption in office environments remains lackluster; however, new hardware releases like Apple's Vision Pro have the potential to catalyze a shift towards mass market uptake for professional use.
The Design, Editing and Rendering Software industry gleams brightly as ray-tracing technology redefines realism in digital realms.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Decentralization Waves Hit Content Creation Shores
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Revolutionary leaps in accessible technology are buoying a trend toward decentralized and single-person production studios, reshaping the revenue stream.

industry_definition: This industry develops and distributes design, picture-editing, video-rendering, object-rendering and audio-editing software. These types of software are widely used in the fields of graphic design, architecture, video game development, manufacturing and media production. The industry also includes companies that develop software add-ons. This industry does not publish software for editing textual documents (IBISWorld report 51121a).

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: high - decreasing

key_trends: The digitization of entertainment has catapulted digital creative software tools into household names. From advertising and construction to product design and moviemaking, nearly every person has repeated interactions with digitally designed software and hardware each day.
Moving to a subscription model dramatically reduced volatility, but
Challenges still abound. Heavily frontloaded costs, high labor utilization and copyright battles cut off many smaller players, leaving Adobe Inc., Autodesk Inc. and Dassault fortified at the top.

Copyright lawsuits are frequent and fierce for companies creating digital design software. Teams must aggressively copyright new features and hire lawyers to ensure their own software doesn't infringe on other major players.

Venture capital funding supports almost all entrants to digital software, as income does not come in until presales at the earliest. This introduces massive risk, as cut funding can wreck new players, as many were subjected to during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Graphic software products are custom-tailored to a target market. Architects use 3D simulation software; designers use CAD; video editors use timeline software and audio engineers use sound splicers. Demand is relatively inflexible between these packages.

Business users are the most valuable clients, taking hundreds or thousands of license seats. Individuals performing creative work for pay are a smaller subset of all users, while creatives who do not profit typically select free software alternatives.
Entertainment centers mixed with Silicon Valley to create fertile ground for creative software developers in the West. Adobe, Autodesk and Dassault all have offices in this region.

Most locations for creative software development focus on minimizing the industry's most significant cost: labor. Western, southeastern and mid-Atlantic areas have large workforces of talented individuals available, making talent acquisition costs lower than in other regions.
Graphic software products compete on features and price, with support and user experience coming next for most buyers. Adobe
Inc.'s skill in the category and stack of features have allowed the company to control two-fifths of the market.

New entrants can effectively compete with established players with low barriers to entry. Still, few make it outside a specific niche before being bought out by the relevant major design studio. Seed funding for these players also pushes a direct sale more than the long road to overall dominance.

Adobe Inc. dwarfs the rest of the creative industry and is considered a technology powerhouse along with Google, Apple, Microsoft and Amazon. The company's creative suite commands a premium price and its products have clamps on studios, colleges and individual creatives.

The same companies do not typically make digital design and digital art software, as professional use of these packages is segregated. Autodesk is an exception, with 3D design familiarity bleeding into model animation and rigging.

Wages are by far the highest cost for graphics software development houses, as the infrastructure to compile software can cost as little as a few thousand dollars. Highly skilled employees, frequently with college software engineering degrees, can command salaries over $100,000.

Graphic design companies spend heavily on marketing, attempting to connect with the many nonemployers and small business owners purchasing creative software. Whale clients, including schools, universities and offices, will purchase design software on an as-needed basis and do extensive research.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Media and entertainment companies consist of businesses, including film studios, TV production companies and streaming services, which create a product intended to be viewed by an audience for fun or information.

Architecture companies use computer-aided design (CAD) software to design and draft buildings prior to construction. Prior to CAD software, architects would create detailed drafting illustrations by hand with pencil and paper, a highly laborious process requiring most of the math to be done and checked by hand.
Manufacturers include automobile, aerospace, consumer goods and all producers creating products; CAD software has dramatically accelerated the product design process in these industries.

This customer segment includes other types of businesses that use design, editing and rendering software and individuals. As 3D printers became more mainstream, demand for CAD software from individuals increased.

products_and_services.product_description: Image editing is broken down into two forms: in pixel-based image editors, the user can manipulate individual pixels or dots within an image, whereas vector image editors enable the user to manage shapes rendered into a final image.

Computer-aided design (CAD) and other design software are this industry's most economically essential products. CAD software enables users to create detailed 3D and 2D models and diagrams of objects, complete with documentation, including the materials, processes and tolerances associated with the design.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Video Postproduction and Sound Editing Software
products_and_services.product_description: Video and sound editing software are essential tools in the movie, TV, video and music production industries since they enable users to import images, audio and video clips into an existing recorded video and alter the viewing angle and color palette.

Computer graphics software differs from video software by using a 3D world (frequently with a physics simulation) to model objects moving in different perspectives. The chief users of computer animation products are movie production companies (e.g., animation studios like Dreamworks) and video game developers.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Building markets represent a massive fraction of total industry income. Operators' products are used to design, refine and test structures, place utilities, select materials and more. Nearly 100% of major nonresidential construction projects undertaken over the past five years have used industry software in some capacity.

Online marketplaces require significant investment in increasingly interactive media to draw customers away from physical retail. The effort from both sales platforms and sellers to create attractive webpages, video review systems and refined products often necessitates teams purchasing industry software.
Users of design software create webpages, videos, and virtual reality games and supplement almost every piece of digital software. These projects are then distributed to consumers via the internet.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Time Spent on Leisure and Sports
demand_determinants.determinant_description: For many digital design software creators, income is only generated when users consume the media content. When consumers have less time to spend on leisure activities, including watching video content and playing games, creators are less incentivized to dedicate huge budgets to upgrading industry software to create the best media content.

As the marketplace for goods becomes more complex and international, companies must refine products through research and development to compete with inexpensive imports. This often means using CAD and simulations developed by design software programmers in physical goods manufacturing.

business_locations.location_description: The West has been a hotbed of entertainment and software innovation for years, hosting Silicon Valley, Hollywood and Los Angeles only a few hours' drive from each other. California contains over a fifth of all design software offices in the nation, almost twice as concentrated as any other state.

While the Southeast does not carry the name recognition of Western region destinations, it benefits from a massive labor pool, key for an industry defined by its workforce. Florida is also fast becoming a region of start-up activity, generating new graphic software development establishments at an unprecedented rate. Its major entertainment giant, Disney, has several major regional offices to design its theme parks and digital environments.

The Mid-Atlantic region contains the United States' financial heart, making it a strategic area for significant players and design software companies selling to businesses. New York also acts as a labor hub for the entire region, drawing in younger talent, which costs less to hire.

regulations_points.regulation_description: US copyright laws protect copyright owners from the unauthorized reproduction, adaptation, performance, display or distribution of copyright-protected works, including digital design programs. Many laws have been enacted at the national and international levels to protect business authors and any new enterprise must ensure compliance or risk being sued. The current copyright term extends to 70 years past the life of the originator, which means that no computer design software has moved into the public domain.

regulations_points.regulation_title: OpenAI vs. The New York Times
regulations_points.regulation_description: The ongoing litigation between The New York Times and OpenAI punctuates an emerging legal frontier—ownership of AI-generated content. The outcomes could ripple across the industry, seismically affecting all whose design-integrated AI endeavors inexorably leverage vast training data with dubious copyright claims. Regardless of the outcome, the resolution may redefine intellectual property conventions and contour the operational landscape for firms ingrained in generative AI pursuits, reverberating through future investments in creative AI applications.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Artificial intelligence brings image editing back to the forefront
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Image editing is broken down into two forms: in pixel-based image editors, the user can manipulate individual pixels or dots within an image, whereas vector image editors enable the user to manage shapes rendered into a final image. The image editing software segment has significant penetration from freeware and open-source software programs like GIMP and Inkscape. Competition from low-cost alternatives limits the ability of proprietary image editors to penetrate the price-conscious consumer and hobbyist markets. The traditionally powerful image editing segment has expanded due to the rapid distribution of powerful image-editing AI models. However, the margin of running this software is frequently much lower than that of traditional packages.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: VIDEO POST-PRODUCTION AND SOUND EDITING SOFTWARE FIND A HOME WITH INDIVIDUAL USERS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Video and sound editing software are essential tools in the movie, TV, video and music production industries since they enable users to import images, audio and video clips into an existing recorded video and alter the viewing angle and color palette. With third-party software, extension plug-ins can add new features like the ability to import 3D objects and animation. Timeline-based video editors (e.g., Adobe Premiere, Apple's Final Cut) enable users to edit an existing video's frame rate, sequence or audio, analogous to traditional cut-and-paste editing of film reels. Sound editing software enables users to record, edit and create audio content, which can often be used in videos. This share has risen over the past five years with the popularity of video-sharing sites and streaming services.

The chief users of computer animation products are movie production companies (e.g., animation studios like Dreamworks) and video game developers. Animated content often takes more time to develop than videos of a similar length - setting up a wireframe. Hence, characters' and objects' movements seem natural and can take months on their own and building out a digital asset suite is also a highly time and resource-intensive process.

FAQs.question: How has the shift towards conducting business online affected demand for your services?
FAQs.answer: The shift online has opened a new distribution channel for industry companies; the cloud. Through the cloud, customers can pay for services on a subscription basis and receive regular software updates, which is a shift from the previous model which required a large one-time purchase.

FAQs.question: Has technology (i.e. data storage and analytics) changed the type of customers you sell to?
FAQs.answer: Compared to costly one-time purchases, cloud-based solutions are marketable to a wider range of customers as these subscription options enable customers to pay less upfront and develop stronger long-term relationships with developers. Offering supplementary subscriptions such as cloud computing and cloud storage for customer files can bring in additional revenue.

FAQs.question: Is your company strategically located in a beneficial region?
FAQs.answer: To attract the best talent, companies should be aware of the Silicon Valley area of California, Austin, TX, Seattle, WA, New York City and Boston, MA as major tech hubs. The two largest US-based industry companies are based in California. The emergence of remote working conditions and offices has increasingly enabled operators to reassess where they are headquartered.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to rising wages in recent years?
FAQs.answer: The industry as a whole has been exposed to rising wages over the past five years as demand for employees is extremely competitive. Large corporations, including industry operators Adobe and Dassault Systemes, push wages up.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to keep current with changing digital interfaces?
FAQs.answer: It is vital for software developers, especially smaller companies, to be aware of changing consumer preferences. The shift to the cloud is extremely important in this industry, as more customers demand the flexibility and affordability that only the cloud offers.

FAQs.question: Has your company prepared adequately to address the increased security risks posed by digital data storage?
FAQs.answer: Enabling your customers to easily implement security features, including app-based two-factor authentication (2FA), one-time passwords, password manager integration, detailed error logging, and more will go a long way to helping customers feel safer using your software. Companies in this industry should consider a security audit of their product (a pentest) from a reputable external company, as clients often store corporate secrets in industry software files.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: On a state and local level, there are a number of groups that are looking to promote software and technology jobs in their area. Sending employees to group-run events will help continue their education at a relatively low cost while keeping them up-to-date.

FAQs.question: Have any recent regulatory changes significantly affected your operations?
FAQs.answer: Regulation plays a small role in the industry; given the highly fragmented nature of the industry, antitrust litigators generally do not scrutinize industry companies. However, the industry's major players anticipate increased federal scrutiny and regulation.

FAQs.question: Do you have any big projects on the horizon that will require capital financing? Have you taken advantage of lower interests rates since the pandemic began in 2020?
FAQs.answer: Generally speaking, barriers to entry are moderate in this industry. New entrants will be challenged to find and fund the right employees, often the bedrock of any successful company.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins remain high in this industry, carried by large companies like Adobe and Autodesk. Smaller companies typically have low-to-zero profit margins. Some startups pay little attention to profit margins and focus on user acquisition and product development. While this is not necessarily harmful, ensure your company is always thinking about a path to profitability.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and retain qualified staff? Do you offer ongoing training to your staff? Have you adjusted these offerings as a result of the pandemic and remote working conditions?
FAQs.answer: Attracting and keeping highly skilled software developers is a key to continued business success in this industry. Industry operators have handled the pandemic by pivoting to remote working conditions and offering other unique perks. Offering competitive benefits packages, including flexible working locations and focusing on positive corporate impact, may be more valuable than simply increasing the salary on your listing.

FAQs.question: How much time is invested in research and development? What are the costs associated with this?
FAQs.answer: Software publishers must spend large sums of revenue on research and development to release more innovative products to a broader customer base. R&D expenditure is often one of the first costs that can be reduced as revenue growth is limited by external influences. Using a combination of direct customer feedback and internal invention may allow you to discover the needs of your users while generating demand through exciting features.

FAQs.question: Do you have a suite of products that benefit each other? Have you considered developing extensions to work with major players' products?
FAQs.answer: Corporate clients often take into consideration the total cost of ownership for a product suite, including the time it will take to use a given product. If your organization makes multiple related programs, make sure that files, settings and custom code from one can easily be transferred to another.

FAQs.question: How closely do you monitor changes in time spent on consumer leisure activities? Do you attempt to capitalize on these swings, or do you stick to a core market for your products?
FAQs.answer: During the pandemic, consumers switched to preferring private indoor or public outdoor recreation activities. The amount of digital content consumed, primarily through video, spiked. Your company may want to offer discounts on video products to draw in new users or create a more extensive walk-through to make your product easier for newcomers.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in corporate profit? How does higher corporate profit affect demand for your products?
FAQs.answer: Rising corporate profit enables companies to upgrade their software. Since software upgrades are not always considered essential, new software is most often purchased when profit is high. Try targeting business sectors with higher profit margins (assuming similar interest levels) when advertising to maximize revenue generation in the long run.

FAQs.question: Does your company monitor digital transitions of various industries?
FAQs.answer: The level of internet traffic reflects the general adoption of information technology by the private sector. As organizations rely increasingly on information technology, lagging businesses and individuals will be forced to upgrade their systems. Noticing these changes before your competitors could allow you to release a market-specific feature to draw in new users from that industry.
